description: Borrowed from Latin persōna (“mask; character”), of uncertain origin. Possibly from personō (“to sound through”); or from Ancient Greek πρόσωπον (prósōpon, “face; appearance; mask used in ancient theatre to denote a character or, more generally, a social role”); or from Etruscan 𐌘𐌄𐌓𐌔𐌖 (φersu). Doublet of person and parson.

nouns.description: persona (plural personas or personae or personæ)

entries.meaning: A character played by an actor.
(psychology) The mask or appearance one presents to the world.
examples: He keeps his online persona completely separate from his real-world one.

entries.meaning: (marketing, user experience) An imaginary person representing a particular type of client or customer, considered when designing products and services that will appeal to them.
examples: To do so, your organization should create nuanced buyer personas for all relevant market segments or buyer groups that demonstrate affinity to your brand. These buyer personas should include standard demographic information  […]
